questions.content: A progressive wave is described by, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></math>, where <math><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>y</mi></math> are in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and <math><mi>t</mi></math> is in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>. What is the maximum particle velocity?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The given progressive wave is,

y=5sin⁡100πt-2πx.

Particle velocity, vp=dydt=500πcos100πt-2πx

Hence, maximum particle velocity will be,

vpmax=500π m s-1

questions.content: A conducting wire frame is placed in magnetic field which is directed into the paper. The magnetic field is increasing at a constant rate. The directions of induced current in wires A B and C D are
questions.subject: Physics

options.content: B to A and D to C
A to B and C to D
A to B and D to C
B to A and C to D

questions.explanation:
The direction of magnetic field is into the plane and magnetic field is increasing at constant rate. If magnetic field is increasing then magnetic flux also increases in loop.

According to Lenz law electric current is induced in the loop in such a way that it opposes the changing flux.  So to reduce the magnetic flux into the plane  the direction of induced current is anticlockwise which gives the magnetic field out of the plane.

Therefore the direction of induced current  is from D→C→B→A→D  in loop.

The direction of current in wire A B  is from B to A and in  wire  C D is from  D  to C.

questions.content: The orbital velocity of an artificial satellite in a circular orbit just above the earth's surface is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>v</mi></math> . For a satellite orbiting at an altitude of half of the earth's radius, the orbital velocity is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
We know that v=GMR.

For a satellite at an altitude R2,  v1=GMR+R2.

Therefore, v1v=23.

questions.content: A wooden object floats in water kept in a beaker. The object is near a side of the beaker. Let P1, P2, P3 be the pressures at the three points A , B and C of the bottom as shown in the figure. Choose the correct option.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
At a depth h of fluid having density ρ, pressure is given by, P=ρgh, pressure at all the points on the bottom remains same.

As it is clear from the diagram, height of A, B & C is the same. So, according to hydrostatic paradox A , B and C points are at the same pressure.

questions.content: When a body rolls down an inclined plane, it's kinetic energy of rotation is found to be <math><mn>40</mn><mi>%</mi></math> of kinetic energy in translation state. Identify the body from the following options.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Rotational kinetic energy is
KR=12Iω2=12MK2vR2 (∴I=MK2 and v=Rω)
=12Mv2K2R2
Translational kinetic energy is
KT=12Mv2
As per question, KR=40% KT
∴12Mv2K2R2=40%12Mv2  or K2R2=40100=25
For solid sphere, K2R2=25
Hence, the body is solid ball.

questions.content: The P-V diagram of an ideal gas is as shown in the figure. Work done by the gas in the process ABCD is,
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Area under pressure-volume curve gives work done and if the process is clockwise, the work done is positive and if the process is anti-clockwise, the work done is negative.

W=WAB+WBC+WCD

W=-P0V0+0+4P0V0

⇒W=3P0V0

questions.content: A vessel is filled with 0.014 kg Nitrogen gas at a temperature of 27°C. Let the νrms at this temperature be V; then at what temperature the νrms of this gas will be 2V ?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Using vrms=3RTm
or ∴     (vrms)1(vrms)2=T1T2 ( ∵   R and m are constant)
According to question, (vrms)2=2(vrms)1
∴     (vrms)1(vrms)2=27+273T2⇒14=300T2
T2=300×4=1200 K .

questions.content: If Surface tension<math><mi> </mi><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, Moment of Inertia <math><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and Planck's constant <math><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>,</mo></math> were to be taken as the fundamental units, the dimensional formula for linear momentum would be:

Let p∝SaIbhc
[MLT-1]=MT-2aML2bML2T-1c

From comparing the power on both side
a+b+c=1 and
2b+2c=1 and
-2a-c=-1
From the above three equations we will get
a=12, b=12 & c=0

Therefore, p∝S12I12h0

questions.content: A train is traveling with a uniform velocity of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>−</mo><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mtext>  </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> on a level track. The engine has to exert a force of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> to overcome friction. The power of the engine is

Suppose the train is travelling with a uniform velocity v→. The power exerted by the engine P=F→·v→

⇒P=(i^-3j^+2k^)·(2i^-j^+4k^)

⇒P=2+3+8=13 W

questions.content: In a double slit arrangement, fringes are produced using light of wavelength <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4800</mn><mo> </mo><mover><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mover></math>. One slit is covered by a thin plate of glass of refractive index <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and the other with angular glass plate of the same thickness, but of refractive index <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. By doing so, the central bright fringe shifts to original fifth bright fringe from the centre. Thickness of glass plate is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Let the fringe width be β.

Shift due to first glass plate, (μ=1.4)

∆y=nβ ∴nλ=μ-1t

⇒∆y=βλ(μ-1)t

∆y1=0.4βtλ

Shift due to second glass plate, (μ=1.7)=βλ(μ-1)t

∆y2=0.7βtλ

Net shift, ∆y2-∆y1=0.3βtλ  (i)

Given, Δy=5β  (ii)

Equating equation (i) and equation (ii)

Hence, 5β=0.3βλt

⇒t=5λ0.3

⇒ t=5×4800×10-100.3

⇒t=8×10-6m

⇒t=8 μm

questions.content: An earthen pitcher loses <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of water per minute due to evaporation. If the water equivalent of pitcher is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kg</mi></math> and the pitcher contains <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kg</mi></math> of water, calculate the time required for the water in the pitcher to cool to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>28</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> from its original temperature of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Neglect radiation effects. Latent heat of vapourization of water in this range of temperature is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>580</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and specific heat of water is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kcal</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>kg</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
As water equivalent of pitcher is 0.5 kg, i..e., pitcher is equivalent to 0.5 kg of water, heat to be extracted from the system of water and pitcher for decreasing its temperature from 30 to 28 °C is

Q1=m+McΔT
=9.5+0.5kg 1 kcal/kgC∘30-28 ∘C
= 2 0 kcal

And heat extracted from the pitcher through evaporation in t minutes

Q2=mL=dmdt×tL=1gmin×t580calg

               =580×tcal

According to given problem Q2=Q1,  i.e., 580×t=20×103⇒t = 34.5 min

questions.content: The sum of two forces acting at a point is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>16</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>. If the resultant force is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>8</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and its direction is perpendicular to minimum force, then the forces are:
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Let the two forces be A and B.



It is given that the resultant of two forces be, 8 N
and, A+B=16 N.

Let the minimum force be, B.
Then, Acosβ=R .....1
and, Asinβ=-B .........2

Squaring and adding equation 1 and 2, we get,
A2cos2β+A2sin2β=R2+B2
A2cos2β +sin2β=82+B2
A2-B2= 64
(A-B)(A+B)=64
(A-B)=6416 N=4 N

A-B=4 N .........3
A+B=16 N .......4

Adding 3 and 4, we get,
2A=20 N⇒A=10 N
Substituting the value of A, we get,
B=6 N.

questions.content: The moment of inertia of a thin rod of length <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>L</mi></math> and mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>M</mi></math> about an axis passing through a point at a distance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> from one of its ends and perpendicular to the rod is,
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Moment of inertia of a rod about an axis passing through its centre of mass and perpendicular to the rod is, I1=ML212.
In given situation, d=L2-L3
⇒d=L6.

Using parallel axis theorem,

I2=I1+Md2
⇒I2=ML212+ML62
⇒I2=ML212+ML236
⇒I2=ML29.

questions.content: The two light beams having intensities <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>I</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn><mi>I</mi></math> interfere to produce a fringe pattern on a screen. The phase difference between the beams is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> at point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>π</mi></math> at point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Q</mi></math>. Then the difference between the resultant intensities at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Q</mi></math> will be :
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Resultant intensity is given by, Iresultant=I1+I2+2I1I2cosϕ

At P, IP=9I+I+29I×Icosπ2=10I

At Q, IQ=9I+I+29I×Icosπ=10I-2×3I=4I

Now, difference between intensities is 10I-4I=6I

questions.content: Nucleus <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> having <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and equal number of protons and neutrons has <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>MeV</mi></math> binding energy per nucleon. Another nucleus <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> has total <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>26</mn></math> nucleons and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>8</mn><mo> </mo><mi>MeV</mi></math> binding energy per nucleons. The difference of binding energy of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> will be ______ <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>MeV</mi></math>.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
In A, Z=17 and have equal numbers of protons and neutrons i.e. nucleons=2×17=34

So, for A, 

Total binding energy BEA=1.2×34=40.8 MeV

Another nucleus B mass number =26

So, total binding energy of  B is BEB=1.8×26 MeV=46.8 MeV

Difference of BE=BEB-BEA=6 MeV

questions.content: For the circuit given below, if the current in the 1 Ω resistor is x23 A, what is the value of x? Assume the batteries are ideal.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The circuit given in the problem can be redrawn as shown below. 

The three branches are connected between the same points P and Q and hence they are in parallel. For such a circuit the potential difference between the points P and Q is

VQP=E1R1+E2R2+E3R31R1+1R2+1R3

Where E1, E2 and E3 are the emf of the batteries present in the first, second and the third branch.

Similarly, R1, R2 and R3 are the values of resistance in each of the respective branches.

VQP=63+01+9513+11+15=5723 V

 The value of current through the 1 Ω resistance is

i=VQP1=5723 A

questions.content: In the given circuit, the value of current IL will be _____ mA. (When RL=1 kΩ)
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Potential drop across the branch containing load resistance will be 5 V due to Zener diode. Therefore, potential drop across 800 Ω will be, 10 V-5 V=5 V.

Now, current through battery will be,

I=5800×1000 =6.25 mA

Current through load will be,

IL=51000 A

=5 mA

questions.content: An object when placed in front of a plano-convex lens forms a real image at a distance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> behind the lens. The wavelength of light that is inside the lens is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> times the wavelength in free space. The radius of the curved surface of the lens in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>α</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, write the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>α</mi></math>?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
μ=λvacuum λmed =43

Given, v=+10 m, m=-14=vu

∴  u=vm=-40 m

Using lens formula,

1f=1v-1u=110--140

∴  1f=540  ⇒f=8 m

For plano-convex lens,

1f=(μ-1)1R

∴Radius of curvature

R=f(μ-1)=843-1=83

questions.content: A resistance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi>R</mi></mfenced></math>, inductance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi>L</mi></mfenced></math> and capacitance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi>C</mi></mfenced></math> are connected in series to an <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> source of voltage <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> having variable frequency. If the energy delivered by the source to the circuit during one period if the operating frequency is twice the resonance frequency is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi><mi>R</mi><msqrt><mi>L</mi><mi>C</mi></msqrt><msup><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mfenced><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mi>C</mi></mfrac></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math>, find <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><mi>m</mi></math>.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Given, 

ω=2ω0=2LC, T=πLC and  XL=ωL=2LC; 

XC=1ωC=12LC

The formula of average power in terms of power factor, 

P=VI cosϕ, here the value of power factor,

 cosϕ=RZ=RXL-XC2+R2

⇒P=V2RR2+XL-XC2

Energy supplied,

 E=PT=πRV2LCR2+2.25LC

Therefore, m=2.25 & 100m=225.

questions.content: Two electric dipoles of dipole moments <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi>cm</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi>cm</mi></math> are placed in two difference uniform electric fields of strengths <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> respectively. The ratio of maximum torque experienced by the electric dipoles will be <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac></math>. The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> is _____ .
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Maximum torque experienced by an electric dipole is τmax=PEsin90°.

So, τmax=PE

The ratio is τ1τ2=P1E1P2E2=1.2×10-30×5×1042·4×10-30×15×104=16
 

Hence, the value of x=6.

questions.content: A particle is moving with constant acceleration a. Following graph shows v2 versus x (displacement) plot. The acceleration of the particle is _________ m s-2.

questions.content:
It requires 68 eV of energy to excite the electron from the second Bohr orbit to the third Bohr orbit in a particular single electron species having a nuclear charge of +Ze, where Z is a constant and e is the magnitude of the electronic charge. Figure out the value of Z.

(The ground state energy of hydrogen atom is -13.6 eV)
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The energy required to excite the electron from secondn=2 Bohr orbit to the thirdn=3 Bohr orbit is given by,

ΔE=E3-E2

=-Z2×13.632--Z2×13.622

=Z2×13.614-19

=Z2×13.6×536 eV  ….(i)

 But ΔE=E3-E2=68 eV   ...ii

From equations (i) and (ii),

∴  68 eV=Z2×13.6×536eV

⇒Z2=365×6813.6=36⇒Z=6

questions.content: Which of the following carbocations is most stable?
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.chapter: Some Basic Principles of Organic Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Carbocation acquires stability if its positive charge is delocalised or there is some atom or a group that can compensate for the electron deficiency of the carbon bearing the positive charge.

Amongst the following carbocations we can list out the following stabilising features.

(A) 

 

Aromatic delocalisation of the positive charge

(B)

Aromatic delocalisation and +M effect of the alkoxy group. The p-methoxy benzyl carbocation has a more stable resonance structure due to the electron-donating nature of the methoxy group. The resonance structure of p-methoxy benzyl carbocation involves the delocalisation of the positive charge to the oxygen atom of the methoxy group.

(C)

Aromatic delocalisation and +I effect of the methyl group

(D)

Only inductive and hyper conjugation effects

Hence, p-methoxy benzyl carbocation is most stable.

(b) further react with MeMgBr/H3O+ to give tert-butanol. 
(c) also be obtained by the ozonolysis of 2, 3-dimethyl-2-butene.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
The alkyl group of the Grignard reagent is electron rich and hence, can act as a nucleophile. The carbonyl compounds can undergo nucleophilic addition reaction which proceeds in such a way that the positive part of the Grignard reagent MgX+ combines with oxygen and the negative part R- binds with the electron deficient carbon of the carbonyl group.

Ethyl acetate reacts with one mole of methyl magnesium bromide by nucleophilic addition elimination reaction to form acetone. Hence, product 'A' is acetone.

Acetone can react with one more mole of methyl magnesium bromide followed by acid hydrolysis to form 2-methyl propan-2-ol (tert-butanol).

Acetone being a methyl ketone can participate in the iodoform reaction.

Acetone can also be obtained by the ozonolysis of 2, 3-dimethyl-2-butene.

questions.content:
Outermost electronic configurations of four elements A,B,C,D are given below:

(A) 3s2

(B) 3s23p1

(C) 3s2 3p3

(D) 3s2 3p4

The correct order of first ionisation enthalpy for them is
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.explanation:
The ionisation enthalpy of an element can be defined as the amount of energy required to remove an electron from an isolated gaseous atom in its gaseous state. Ionisation enthalpy depends on the following factors:

  1. Penetration effect
  2. Shielding effect
  3. Electronic configuration

(A) 3s2→Mg

(B) 3s23p1→Al

(C) 3s23p3→P

(D) 3s23p4→S

Al has one unpaired electron in its highest energy orbital 3p, and Mg has highest energy orbital 3s has the paired electrons.

It is energetically favourable for all the electrons in an orbital to be paired, which means that breaking up this pair would require more energy.

Compared to 16th group, 15 group have high ionisation energy. It is because of the stable half filled configuration of the 15th group elements.

P-3s23p3

S-3s23p4

Therefore, P has more ionisation energy than S.

Hence, the correct order of first ionisation enthalpy is B<A<D<C

questions.content:
Select schemes A, B, C, respectively, out of following


I. Acid catalysed hydration
II. Hydroboration oxidation
III. Oxymercuration - demercuration
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
1. Acid catalysed hydration-
This involves replacing the pi bond on the alkene with water molecules. This mechanism follows Markovnikov's rule i.e. alcohol will add to the more substituted carbon atom and hydrogen to the less substituted carbon atom. Notefully, this reaction can undergo carbocation rearrangement due to presence of acid as a catalyst for the same. Hence, path C is the acid-catalyzed hydration.

2. Hydroboration oxidation-
This mechanism too involves the replacement of the double bond by single bond and formation of an alcohol molecule. This reaction takes place by Anti-Markovnikov's rule i.e. hydroxyl group attaching to the less substituted carbon atom; for the stability of the substituted carbocation. Hence, path A is hydroboration oxidation.

3. Oxymercuration – demercuration-
This is an electrophilic addition of a water molecule across the double bond of alkene compound to give a neutral alcohol. This takes place by Markovnickov’s rule i.e. hydroxyl group attaching to more substituted carbon atom and the hydrogen atom attaching to less substituted carbon atom. Hence, path B is the oxymercuration-demercuration reaction.

questions.content: The elements having the maximum and minimum melting points amongst the members of the group <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>13</mn><mo> </mo></math>respectively are
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Group 13 elements, also known as the boron group, include boron (B), aluminium (Al), gallium (Ga), indium (In), and thallium (Tl).

The melting point in group13 decreases down the group but the trend is not regular. Boron has the highest melting point(2349K) due to its small atomic size. It forms very strong covalent bonds with neighbouring atoms. Therefore, when in solid-state, it requires a lot of energy to break the bonds between atoms. Gallium has a very low melting point (303 K) and therefore could exist in a liquid state during summer.

The bond order shows the number of chemical bonds present between a pair of atoms

questions.content:
The value of ′n′ In the reaction,

Cr2O72-+14H++nFe2+⟶2Cr3++nFe3++7H2O

will be
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Cr2O72-+14H++nFe2+⟶2Cr3++nFe3++7H2O
The two half-equations involved in the above reactions are as follows,
Cr2O72-+14H++6e-⟶2Cr3++7H2O (reduction)...(i)

Fe2+⟶Fe3++e- (oxidation)...(ii)

Equation (ii) is multiplied by 6.

6Fe2+⟶6Fe3++6e-

Thus, the balanced equation is,

Cr2O72-+14H++6Fe2+⟶2Cr3++6Fe3++7H2O

Hence, the value of 'n' is 6.

questions.content: Calculate the osmotic pressure of a decinormal solution of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> at  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>27</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> showing <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>70</mn><mo>%</mo></math> degree of ionization. Round-off your answer to the nearest integer.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Given,  Normality=110 N for BaCl2

Now, we know that,

Molarity=Normalityvalency factor

For salts, the valency factor is equal to the total charge on cations or anions.

Thus, valency factor for BaCl2=2

∴ Molarity =120 for BaCl2

The degree of dissociation is defined as the proportion of the substance that is dissociated, and it is usually expressed as a decimal. The degree of dissociation is often given the symbol α.

Van't Hoff's factor for dissociating solute is equal to the ratio of the number of particles obtained after dissociation to the number of particles before dissociation.

BaCl2→Ba2++2Cl-before dissociation100after dissociation1-αα2α

Thus, i =1-α+α+2α1=1+2α

According to question, for BaCl2, α=0.7

Thus, i=1+2×0.7=1+1.4=2.4

∴π=i×C×R×T=120×2.4×0.0821×300        =2.95 ≈3 atm

questions.content: Two elements <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> which form <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>15</mn></math> moles of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>AB</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> type compounds. If one mole of each <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>AB</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> weigh equally, then the atomic weight of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is____times of atomic weight of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
The molar mass of a substance is the mass in grams of one mole of the compound.

Given: Molar mass of A2B=AB3

∴ 2A+B=A+3BA→Atomic wt. of AB→Atomic wt. of B

⇒A=2 B

∴ Atomic weight of A is 2 times of atomic weight of B.

questions.content:
Figure out the number of reactions among the following which have ΔH equal to ∆U

i. N2g+3H2g⟶2NH3g

ii. 2HIg⟶H2g+I2g

iii. Cs+O2g⟶CO2g

iv. 2NO2g⟶N2O4g

v. 2SO2g+O2g⟶2SO3g

vi. CH4g+2O2g⟶CO2g+2H2Ol

vii. 2C4H10g+13O2g→8CO2g+10H2Ol

viii. H2g+Br2g⟶2HBrg
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Apply the given relationship between the change in enthalpy and the change in internal energy.

∆H=∆U + ∆ngRT

Where ∆ng=(Number of gaseous moles of product - number of gaseous moles of reactants)

ii 2HIg⟶H2g+I2g

iii Cs+O2g⟶CO2g

viii H2g+Br2g⟶2HBrg

For reactions, ii, iii, and viii Δng=0. Hence,
ΔH=ΔU

Therefore, total three reaction are present that have the change in enthalpy is equal to the change in internal energy.

Pd(aq)2++2e-⇌Pd(s)  Eo=0.83 V

PdCl42-(aq)+2e-⇌Pd(s)+4Cl-(aq)

Eo=0.65 V
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Given, 2.303RTF=0.06 V

Using gibbs free energy equation,

ΔG°=-RT lnK

-nFEcell o=-RT×2.303log10 K

ECell00.06×n=log K---------(i)

Pd2+ (aq) + 2e-⇌ Pd(s), Ecathode, reduction 0 = 0.83 V

Pd (s)+4Cl- (aq.) ⇌ PdCl42- (aq) + 2e-, Eanode, oxidationo = 0.65V

Net Reaction →Pd2+ (aq.) + 4Cl- (aq.) ⇌ PdCl42- (aq.)

Ecell o = Ecathode,reductiono - Eanode, oxidation o

⇒ Ecello = 0.83 - 0.65⇒Ecello = 0.18--------(ii)

Also n=2--------(iii)

Using equation (i), (ii) & (iii), we get

ECell00.06×n=log K

⇒ 0.180.06× 2 = log K

⇒ logK = 6

questions.content: Number of complexes which will exhibit synergic bonding amongst, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mrow><mi>Cr</mi><msub><mfenced><mi>CO</mi></mfenced><mn>6</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mrow><mi>Mn</mi><msub><mfenced><mi>CO</mi></mfenced><mn>5</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mrow><msub><mi>Mn</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mfenced><mi>CO</mi></mfenced><mn>10</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced></math> is
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Synergic bonding involves transference of electrons from ligands to metal. The transference of electrons takes place from filled metal orbitals to anti-bonding orbitals of ligands. It is a bond between a carbonyl group acting as a ligand and a metal. Synergic bonding means self strengthening bond. More the number of d electrons on the central metal ion more the synergic bonding. In metal carbonyls' oxidation state of the metal is zero.

In the complex MnCO5, the electronic configuration of Mn is 3d54s2. As carbon monoxide is a strong field, pairing of electrons occurs. Hence, the new electronic configuration of Mn is 3d7.

In the case of Mn2CO10 also electronic configuration after pairing of electrons is 3d7.

In the complex CrCO6 , the electronic configuration of Cr is 3d54s1 . As carbon monoxide is a strong field, pairing of electrons occurs. Hence, the new electronic configuration of Cr is 3d6

All of these compounds can show synergic bonding.

questions.content: The spin-only magnetic moment value of the most basic oxide of vanadium among <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub></math> is____B.M. (Nearest integer)
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Spin only magnetic moment:

When electrons move around freely, they create a magnetic field; this magnetic field created by electron motion is known as the magnetic moment.

A spin-only magnetic moment occurs when an electron rotates on its own axis and generates a magnetic field.

V2O3 is the most basic oxide amongst the given oxides.

In V2O3, Vanadium is in +3 oxidation state

V3+⇒Ar3d24s0

So, 2 unpaired electrons are there,

Its magnetic moment is equal to μ=nn+2 BM Here, n is the number of unpaired electrons.=22+2 BM

=2.83 BM ≃ 3 BM

questions.content: Consider the function fx=a7x-12-x2bx2-7x+12,x<32sin(x-3)x-[x],x>3b,x=3,where [x] denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to x. If S denotes the set of all ordered pairs (a, b) such that f(x) is continuous at x=3, then the number of elements in S is :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given: fx=a7x-12-x2bx2-7x+12,x<32sin(x-3)x-[x],x>3b,x=3

⇒f3-=a7x-12-x2b|x2-7x+12|

⇒f3-=-a(x-3)(x-4)b(x-3)(x-4)

⇒f3-=-ab   ...i

Now, f3+=2limx→3+sin(x-3)x-3

⇒f3+=2   ...ii

Also, f(3) = b   ...iii

It is given that fx is continuous at x=3.

Hence, f(3)=f(3+)=f(3-)

⇒b=2=-ab

⇒b=2, a=-4

Hence, there is only 1 elements in S, which is ordered pair (-4,2).

questions.content: The first of the two samples have <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn></math> items with mean <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>.</mo><mo> </mo><mn>3</mn><mo>.</mo></math> If the whole group has <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>250</mn></math> items with mean <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>6</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>13</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>44</mn></msqrt></math> then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>.</mo></math> of the second group is

questions.explanation:
Let n1=100 & x1=15 and r1=3, be the mean & S.D. of Ist group.

So, n2=250-100=150

and x=15.6, σ=13.44 be the mean & S.D. of the group.

Let, x2 be the mean of II group.

∴x=n1x1+n2x2n1+n2

⇒ 15.6=100×15+150×x2100+150=1500+150x2250

⇒ 3900=1500+150x2

⇒ 150x2=2400

⇒ x2=2400150=16

Let σ2 be the S.D. of II group.

∴ σ2=n1σ12+d12+n2σ22+d22n1+n2

Where, d1=x-x1, d2=x-x2, i.e., d1=15.6-15=0.6, d2=15.6-16=-0.4

⇒ 13.44=10032+0.62+150σ22+0.42250

⇒ 3360=100×9.36+150σ22+150×0.16

⇒3360=936+150σ22+24

⇒150σ22=3360-960=2400

⇒σ22=2400150=16       ∴ σ2=4

Hence, S.D. of second group =4

Option b is correct.

questions.explanation:
Given, system of equations

αx+2y+z=1

2αx+3y+z=1

3x+αy+2z=β

Now finding, D=α212α313α2=0

⇒α(6-α)-2(4α-3)+1(2α2-9)=0

⇒α-3(α+1)=0

⇒α=-1,3

Dx=211311α2β=0⇒β=2

⇒2β-2-1(3β-α)+(6-α)=0

⇒β=2

Dy=α112α1132β=0

⇒α(β-2)-1(2αβ-3)+1(4α-3)=0

⇒α(2-β)=0

⇒α=0,β=2

Dz=α212α313αβ=0

⇒α2-αβ-3=0

Now when β=2,α=-1 the system of equations will have infinite solutions,

When α=3, β=2 the system has infinite solution,

And when α=3, β≠2 the system has no solution as Dx & Dy≠0 for β≠2,

Hence, only option B is not correct

questions.content: Let S=z=x+iy:2z-3i4z+2i is a real number }. Then which of the following is NOT correct?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
We have,

Z=2z-3i4z+2i

⇒Z=2x+i2y-34x+i4y+2

⇒Z=2x+i2y-34x+i4y+2×4x-i4y+24x-i4y+2

⇒Z=8x2+4y+22y-3+i4x2y-3-8xy+4x16x2+4y+22

Since, Z is purely real, so 4x2y-3-8xy+4x16x2+4y+22=0

⇒-12x+8xy-8xy+4x=0

⇒x=0

And,

4x+i4y+2≠0

⇒i4y+2≠0

⇒y≠-12

Hence this is the required option.

questions.explanation:
Given: Line AC: 2x-y=2 and BD: x=y.

Line AC and BD intersects at point D.

⇒2x-x=2

⇒x=y=2

⇒D≡2,2

We know that, by angle bisector theorem, the angle bisector of a triangle divides the base in the same ratio as the other two sides.

⇒CDAD=BCAB

It is given that, 2AB=BC.

⇒CDAD=2ABAB

⇒CD:AD=2:1

Let the coordinates of C be h,k.

By using section formula,

D≡h×1+2×43,1×k+2×63=2,2

⇒h+8=6, k+12=6

⇒h=-2, k=-6

⇒C≡-2,-6

Now, 2AB=BC

⇒24-α2+6-β2=α+22+β+62

Also, B lines on x=y.

⇒44-α2+6-α2=α+22+α+62

⇒416+α2-8α+36+α2-12α=α2+4+4α+α2+36+12α

⇒8α2-80α+208=2α2+16α+40

⇒6α2-96α+168=0

⇒α2-16α+28=0

⇒α-14α-2=0

⇒α=2,14

But, coordinates of B and D cannot be same.

⇒α=β=14

⇒α+2β=42

questions.content:
Among the relations
S=a,b:a,b∈R-0,2+ab>0 and T=a,b:a,b∈R,a2-b2∈Z,
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

a, b ∈ I and relation T is defined as a2-b2∈I

Now if a2-b2∈I so b2-a2 will also be integer, for example if 52-42=9 is integer then 42-52=-9 is also a integer,

Now checking transitive,

If 42-32=7 is an integer, 32-22=5 is an integer then 42-22=12 is also an integer, hence we can say that T is symmetric and transitive,

 Now checking relation S which is defined as 2+ab>0,

So, if we replace ab by -19 then 2+ab>0 is true but we take ba=-9 for symmetric we get 2+ba=2-9=-7≯0 hence, the relation is not symmetric, 

Now checking transitive, now if 2+ab>0⇒ab>-2 and bc>-2 then we cannot say that ac>-2,

For example if we take 41>-2, 1-1>-2 then 4-1≯-2, hence it is not transitive,

Hence, we can say that  T is symmetric and S is not.

Solving i & ii, we get

Distance of point P23,46,19 from the plane z+9=0 is

=19+902+02+12=28 units

as (a→×b→)·a→=(a→×b→)·b→=0

Again, applying dot product with b→ on both sides of equation i

Now, using equation i

questions.content: Let f:S→S where S=0,∞ be a twice differentiable function such that fx+1=xfx. If g:S→R be defined as gx=logefx, then the value of g''5-g''1 is equal to :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

fx+1=xfx

⇒lnfx+1=lnxfx

⇒lnfx+1=lnx+lnfx

⇒gx+1=lnx+gx

⇒gx+1-g(x)=lnx

⇒  g''x+1-g''x=-1x2

Put x=1,2,3,4

g''2-g''1=-112 ...1

g''3-g''2=-122 ...2

g''4-g''3=-132 ...3

g''5-g''4=-142 ...4

Add all the equations we get

g''5-g''1=-112-122-132-142

⇒g"5-g"1=205144

cosA·cos2A·cos22A·cos23A.....·cos2n-1A=sin2nA2nsinA

Now using the above formula in given expression we get,

=96×sin32π3325sinπ33

=96×sinπ-π3325sinπ33

=96×sinπ3325sinπ33 as sinπ-α=sinα

=96×132=3

questions.content:
Let p and p+2 be prime numbers and let
Δ=p!p+1!p+2!p+1!p+2!p+3!p+2!p+3!p+4!
Then the sum of the maximum values of α and β, such that pα and p+2β divide Δ, is _______.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

Δ=P!P+1!P+2!P+1!P+2!P+3!P+2!P+3!P+4!

Now using the factorial concept and taking common terms we get,

⇒Δ=P!P+1!P+2!111P+1P+2P+3P+2P+1P+3P+2P+4P+3

Now on solving determinant we get,  111P+1P+2P+3P+2P+1P+3P+2P+4P+3

Using operation C1→C1-C2 & C2→C2-C3

001-1-1P+3-2P-4-2P-6P+4P+3

=2P+6-2P+4=2

Now putting the value of determinant we get,

⇒Δ=2P!P+1!P+2!

⇒Δ=2P3P-1!P+1P-1!P+2P+1P-1!

Which is divisible by Pα and P+2β

So, α=3,β=1

questions.content: The sum of all those terms, of the arithmetic progression <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>13</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>373</mn></math>, which are not divisible by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math>, is equal to ________.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given sequence is 3,8,13,.....373.

Here a=3, d=5 and an=373

Now an=a+n-1d

⇒373=3+n-15

⇒n=75

We know that Sn=n2a+an

⇒S75=7523+373

⇒S75=14100

Now let us write the sequence of terms which are divisible by 3.

We get, 3,18,33,.....363

⇒363=3+n-115

⇒n=25

Now let us find the sum of terms divisible by 3.

⇒Sdiv by 3=2523+363=4575

Required sum =Sum of 75 terms-Sum of terms divisible by 3

=14100-4575

=9525.

Therefore, the required sum is 9525

questions.content:
The constant term in the expansion of
2x+1x7+3x25 is _____ .
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Any term in the expansion of 2x+1x7+3x25 is given by

5!a!·b!·c!2xax-7b3x2c

 where a+b+c=5   ...i

=2a3c5!a!·b!·c!xax-7bx2c

=2a3c5!a!·b!·c!xa-7b+2c

Now for term to be independent of x, we know

a-7b+2c=0   ...ii

Solving i & ii, we get

b=c+58

Also, a, b, c∈1,2,3,4,5

So, a=1, b=1, c=3

Therefore, the term independent of x will be 

2133·5!1!·1!·3!=1080

questions.content: Consider a parallelogram constructed on the vectors <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mover accent="true"><mi>q</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mover accent="true"><mi>q</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>.</mo></math> If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mover><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mfenced open="|" close="|" separators="|"><mover><mi>q</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo></math> the angle between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>q</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> and the length of the smaller diagonal of the parallelogram is <math><mi>k</mi></math> units, then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is equal to
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Diagonals of the parallelogram are A→+B→, A→-B→

=6p→-q→,4p→+5q→

A→+B→=36p→2+q→2-12p→⋅q→

=144+25-12×2×5×cosπ3

=109

A→-B→=16p→2+25q→2+40p→⋅q→

=16×4+25×25+40×2×5×cosπ3

=889

So, length of the smaller diagonal is 109 units

questions.explanation:
Given, 2αn+3βn=3+22n             .....i

Rationalizing we get, 2αn-3βn2αn2-3βn2=3-22n

⇒2αn-3βn=3-22n     .....ii

i+ii⇒αn=3+22n+3-22n22

i-ii⇒βn=3+22n-3-22n23

Now, αnβn=323+22n+3-22n3+22n-3-22n

limn→∞αnβn=321+3-223+22n1-3-223+22n=32,

As 3-223+22→0, as n→∞

So, 4p2=4×322=9

questions.explanation:
Given,

p4+q4=369⇒p2+q22-2pq2=369

⇒p+q2-2pq2-2pq2=369

⇒9-2pq2-2pq2=369

⇒pq2-18pq-144=0  ⇒pq=24(rejected),-6

Now, 1p+1q-2=pq2p+q2=pq29=4

Let I=∫0π260sin6xsinxdx

⇒I=120∫0π23-4sin2x1-4sin2xcosxdx

Now let sinx=t⇒cosxdx=dt and limit changes to 0 to 1,

So, I=120∫013-4t21-4t2dt

⇒I=1203t-16t33+16t5501

⇒I=1203-163+165=120×45-80+4815=8×13=104
